question: Question_06
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show your work.
Full simplification of numerical answers is required unless explicitly
stated otherwise.}

Using the definition of the derivative, compute $\displaystyle f'(x)$ if
$\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x}{2x+1}$. No marks will be given for the
use of differential rules, but you may use them to check your answer.
hints:
The derivative of $f$ at $x$ is the slope of the line tangent to $f$ at
$x$. What is the expression for the slope of a line?

The slope of a line between two points $\displaystyle (x_1, f(x_1))$ and
$\displaystyle (x_2, f(x_2))$ is $\frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{x_2 - x_1}$.
What happens as $\displaystyle x_2 - x_1 \to 0$? How can we express this
mathematically?

The limit definition of the derivative of $f$ at $x$ is
$f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}$.\\\\Equivalently, the
derivative of $f$ at $a$ is
$f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a}\frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}$.
